Funding for home and EU graduate students normally comes from the Arts
and Humanities Research Council. The AHRC offers two sorts of grant:
one year awards for M.Phil. courses and the like ('Research Preparation
Master's Scheme') and three year awards for the Ph.D. ('Doctoral Awards
Scheme'). The advice contained on this page applies to both types of award.
Awards cover both fees and maintenance. The deadline for applications for
both types of award is May 1st. This is an absolute deadline,
and the AHRC will not consider any application after that date. You need
to have already been accepted for your proposed course before you
apply to the AHRC. That means that you should apply promptly for your chosen
course, and that you would be well advised to apply to several institutions

The AHRC is very keen that students should normally do an M.Phil. or similar
course before they proceed to the Ph.D. The reason for this is that experience
has shown that students who have had proper training in research methods
are more likely to complete their Ph.D. dissertations promptly. The practical
consequences of this policy is that the AHRC almost always only gives three
year grants to students who already have completed an M.Phil. course or
equivalent. You should bear this fact in mind when you decide which course
you should apply for. If you have not already obtained an M.Phil. qualification
or equivalent and your interests lie in an area in which the Faculty does
not offer an M.Phil. course (such as twentieth century British poetry) it
may be in your interests to consider taking a one year course at another
institution before you apply for a Ph.D. here.
The AHRC's criteria for awarding grants are:
<li>That your research proposal promises to make a contribution to knowledge
and is sufficiently self-contained to be completed within the period of
your course. (For this reason your proposal should clearly say how you
plan to go beyond the existing state of knowledge in your proposed subject
area, and you should give clear conceptual, generic or chronological limits
to the materials you propose to cover)
<li>Your qualifications for the proposed course. (Your topic should ideally
be related to your choice of options as an undergraduate, or to the subject
areas in which your undergraduate performance so far has been strongest)
<li>The suitability of the institution at which you wish to study to the
topic which you propose. (It is a good idea to mention in your proposal
the holdings of the University Library in your proposed area or the presence
in Cambridge of a particular supervisor with whom you wish to work).
The Faculty also takes account of all these criteria when it comes to assess
applications, so it is well worth giving serious thought to your proposal,
even if you are applying for an M.Phil. course. <a href="../faculty/index.htm">Members
of the Faculty may be willing to give advice on how best to present
The AHRC is very keen to ensure that rates of submission of Ph.D.s remain
at an acceptable level. They have recently stated that any institution in
which submission rates among AHRC funded students fall below 50% will be
blacklisted. This means that those institutions will not be allowed to have
any AHRC funded students for two years. The Faculty is consequently extremely
keen to ensure that all AHRC funded students submit work to their supervisors
regularly, and that they remain on course to submit their dissertations
within three years. This makes it particularly important to devise an area
of study which can be completed swiftly.
